column13: The fellow presented a lesson reflecting reading comprehension. She utilized different instructional tools (Smart Board, document camera, tactile manipulatives) to engage the students and differentiate instruction. The students demonstrated a learned procedure for answering comprehension questions and commenting on the ideas of others. The fellow listed the expectations for the corresponding writing activity and referred to previous student work products for reference. The fellow was able to complete the mini-lesson and writing period within the parameters of the lesson plan. Transitions from one section of the lesson to the next was seamless.
column17: The students were engaged by the material presented on the Smart Board. The fellow assessed their prior knowledge in order to guide the comprehension questions and discussion. Students were respectful of one another and each had the opportunity to share their thoughts. Compliance during the mini-lesson was strong. The fellow had tested the technology prior to the start of the lesson, which is an ideal routine/practice. Students exhibited frustration during the writing activity. The fellow is aware of the challenges writing assignments present in terms of actual handwriting and forming ideas. She attempted to address the frustration by allowing students to write open-ended responses and listing the expectation of only a couple of sentences.
column21: The fellow guided the students through a discussion of "right and wrong" in connection with a read aloud. She prompted students to reference the story elements in order to support their answers. The fellow provided prompts and modeling as each student was given an opportunity to make a text-to-self or text-to-world-connection. A written task was selected in order to assess the comprehension of the students. Writing has been a challenge for these students, perhaps, a multiple choice or fill-in activity was best suited for this lesson. The goal was to assess student understanding of the characters' choices. The writing task and the stamina necessary to complete it may effect the measurement of comprehension.
column23: The fellow is in the process of understanding modeling, active engagement, and assessment. She is eager to improve in these areas by experimenting with different types of strategies e.g. timer or peer tutoring. column13: I observed Raphael in a self contained class. I wasn't provided with a lesson plan nor was a class agenda displayed, therefore I was unaware of what subject I was observing.    The lesson was not planned nor did it have an agenda for students to follow, therefore the lesson was instructed without a do-now, lead lesson, activity, or closing. Students were told to sit in a circle and taught how to greet one another respectively and I was unsure of the learning objective for the entire period.    I encouraged Raphael to:    1. Plan his lessons in advance and design them around specific units.  2. Have a visual class agenda, class procedures, and a content decorated room visible.   3. Implement a do-now, guided lesson, activity, and closing,  4. Establish classroom rules and procedures.  5. Utilize the paraprofessional in the room to support and assist you.  6. Design projects and group activities to not only support learning but to minimize behavioral issues.

column13: Ms. Armand displayed a solid knowledge of the Math 7 curriculum by including the Common Core Learning Standards in her lesson plan.    The lesson objective stated that students will be able to identify proportional and non-proportional relationships using data tables. This objective represents rigorous and important learning within the math curriculum.    The instructional activity included a chart with time in minutes in one row, and miles per hour in the other. The students’ task was to determine whether or not the relationship was proportional, and then reduce the answer to its lowest form. A similar chart was offered for the number of copies from a copy machine and the charges for 25, 50, 100, and 500 copies. Students again had to determine whether or not the relationships were proportional. They also had to state which relationship included the lowest charge per copy. These activities represented a significant cognitive challenge to students. The time allotted for the activity was appropriate for all the students.
column17: Ms. Armand’s class exhibits characteristics of a cognitively busy environment where students and teacher both value learning. It is evident that Ms. Armand holds high expectations for her students, and most of them understand their role and expend efforts to learn.    Effective classroom routines and procedures maximized instructional time. Ms. Armand managed instructional groups effectively.    Student behavior was generally appropriate, however, this group of 7th grades exhibited a propensity to be chatty. Ms. Armand utilized planned ignoring and proximity of control, which reduced most of these off-task behaviors. A few students were chronic chatters, which led to a number of disruptions, eventually culminating in Ms. Armand threatening students that they would stay after school to complete their classwork.
column21: Ms. Armand utilized directed and critical thinking questions to drive instruction and student understanding. She posed questions such as, “What is a proportional relationship?” and “Why are they proportional?” Her questions were largely single line of inquiry, however, she did attempt to get most of the students to respond to questions during the lesson.    All of the students were cognitively engaged throughout the lesson. The pace of the lesson, as well as questioning wait time, afforded students the ability to digest the information and formulate a verbal or written response. Ms. Armand grazed the classroom frequently to assist students during group work.    Assessment was incorporated throughout the lesson. Posed questions yielded responses from a number of students. Ms. Armand would not accept the first response, but successfully was able to tease answers from a number of students before settling on the correct answer. During independent practice, Ms. Armand actively circulated the class to check the pulse of understanding of each group.
column23: Ms. Armand participated in our post observation conference following the lesson. She was praised for her solid presence and overall effective lesson delivery. She exhibited a command and a comfort level with the material, which supported student efforts in grasping and internalizing the lesson objective. Although the board space in this classroom is very small, Ms. Armand’s board work was very neat, understandable and sequential. Ms. Armand explained that her principal was in the process of getting her a computer projector. This would help Ms. Armand to display questions and notes on the screen, freeing up board space for guided practice and problem review.     Ms. Armand’s teaching was methodical. She task analyzed the work, allowing students to visualize the step-by-step process of analyzing and solving problems.    We discussed differentiation and student supports in general. She explained that she did not receive any information as of yet as to who her special education students actually are, although she does have her suspects.  I advised her to check her student’s programs to see if any of them receive SETTS, and then contact their special education teacher to get information about her students.     We had a discussion pertaining to positive behavioral supports in the classroom. Class rules were developed collectively, however, many of her students have difficulty consistently following them. It was noted that a significant component of behavioral supports includes praise and effective feedback from the teacher. She agreed that she has an issue in this area. She also added that her summer coaches also commented on her lack of praise. In addition to praising students for following rules and showing their best effort, we also discussed the use of employing effective feedback consistently. Evaluative comments from the teacher related to positive behavior and effective work efforts afford students a gauge to measure their own efforts and build their self- confidence. Ms. Armand possesses many of the traits and skills of an effective teacher. Including positive comments and feedback in her teaching will assist her tremendously.

column13: Ms.Vieria displayed a solid understanding of the 6th grade ELA curriculum by including the Common Core Learning Standards in her lesson plan. She also included a medial and culminating summary, which directly related to the lesson objective.    The lesson objective stated that students would be able to determine the mood of a text. This objective represents important learning within the 6th grade ELA curriculum.    The learning activity asked students to construct their own poem in the style of Maya Angelou’s “Life Doesn’t Frighten Me.” They were instructed to choose two things that frighten them that they want to overcome and say, “Life doesn’t frighten me at all.” They had to write at least 3 stanzas in their poem.
column17: The classroom culture was cognitively where students and teacher shared the common belief that working hard and accepting responsibility for one’s learning is the expectation. Students initiated discussions and seamlessly helped their peers to revise their poems to meet the expected standard.    Efficient classroom routines and procedures maximized and enhanced instructional time. The construct of the class helped students to manage their instructional groups by exhibiting and communicating their needs to their peers and teacher.    There were no behavioral issues in Ms.Vieria’s class. She has established a very healthy rapport and respect level with her students. She is extremely positive and quick to praise. She communicates her expectations to her students, which truly empowers them to behave in a mature and respectful manner.
column21: Ms.Vieria’s questions challenged students cognitively and promoted group and student-to-student discussions. Students were able to critique their peer’s work and formulate questions that contributed to the overall learning experience for their peers. Questions such as, “How can you determine the mood of a text? and “Why do rhymes help you to feel happy” were presented during the class.    Virtually all students were intellectually engaged throughout the lesson. Ms.Vieria utilized ample wait time during questioning, enabling students to understand the question and formulate an appropriate response. The pace of the lesson, as well as appropriate scaffolding enhanced students’ ability to engage and understand the material. Students reflected on their work and their classmates’ work during critiquing sessions. Students are in the process of learning accountable talk, however, their comments to their partners and their classmates were sensitive and constructive.    Ms.Vieria incorporated formative checks of understanding throughout the lesson. She expanded the assessment process more fully during the medial and final summaries where students were required to answer questions in a written fashion, and then discuss their answers with their partner.
column23: Ms.Vieria’s teaching exhibited characteristics and skills beyond expectations for a first year teacher. She was poised and prepared and her upbeat personality and high energy truly inspired students to have fun, contribute and work hard. She promoted student-to-student discussions with her questioning and learning activities. At the post observations conference, we also discussed the need for Ms.Vieria to distribute verbal questions to many more students and incorporate the redirection and web of questioning strategies to encourage more students to offer their responses.     Ms.Vieria was reflective and open to praise, as well as suggestions to improve her pedagogical skills.

column13: I observed a Shared Reading lesson for the teaching fellow, however, I was not presented with a lesson and was told that there was no lesson she would be able to share with me.  I saw a shell of the lesson and I described to her how important the lesson is because I was unclear what the lesson was.  After she explained to me her objective I told her that was basically called context clues.  The lesson was a picture walk, then continued by labeling the pictures with post-it notes to show the students how to spell the words and add to the sight words and new vocabulary in the class.  Students were able to understand the pictures of the words that were animals.  When she began to describe words that were difficult, the students tried to define the word.  The one word that was difficult for the students was stuck.  She asked the students what was the word, "stuck" mean.  There were varying answers.  I think that a definition from the teacher would have been more effective as the word stuck can mean a few things - transportation (outside of self), movement (self, animal, or insect, etc.), and thinking or inability to think (not sure of an idea).   We discussed this and determined that we will observe this for our next lesson.  Using words and describing the definition  with something they can relate to that is different than the text.

column23: Ms. Zheng actively participated in the post observation conference. She was upset that she forgot her laptop computer. Her knowledge of the Algebra curriculum was significant, however, transferring that knowledge to her students was a bumpy road.    Ms. Zheng and I discussed the entire lesson, which actually was largely based on a 30 minute Do Now. Ms. Zheng assumed that students’ prior knowledge was sufficient enough to understand the work they were presented for interpreting functions of graphs and various applications of mathematical terms. Students were unclear and lacked a conceptual understanding of the functional vocabulary and terms. The lesson was incoherent and disjointed at times, with Ms. Zheng and a few students largely supplying information for the class. Assessment of student understanding and learning was haphazard and incomplete. Ms. Zheng reported that her students did well on the exit ticket.    Ms. Zheng and I spent some time discussing a math developmental lesson. We talked about questioning and the need for consistent redirection and a web of questioning.    Ms. Zheng is very bright and has some great ideas. She numbered each task with coordinates and used the students at those desks to stand when their coordinates were called. column21: Ms. Martin’s questions were largely single line of inquiry or procedural how to type questions. She did design questions to promote student understanding, however, only a few students were involved.    The learning task was designed to challenge student thinking, however, most students were only passively compliant. Only a single guided practice problem was performed, and the pace was rather brisk, resulting in many students not truly understanding how to perform the box method to solve quadratic equations.    After the first guided practice problem, Ms. Martin asked the class if they understood. Very few students acknowledged the question. She followed with an invitation to join her at the front table for further reinforcement of the box method. The other students were given a worksheet to work on independently. Four students joined the four already sitting at the table. After 15 minutes, half the class required remediation. It was obvious that only one guided practice problem was insufficient to develop student understanding. Evidence of learning was not present, since thorough formative checks of student understanding were not implemented.
column23: Ms. Martin and I met for a post observation conference. She was praised for the positive rapport she was in the process of building with her students, and that it was evident that students respected her.    I asked Ms. Martin about her summer teaching experience, and she said it went fairly well. We discussed the elements of a developmental lesson and the sections it consisted of. Basically, we discussed a lesson from the learning objective through summary and reflection.  We focused on guided and independent practice as being key components whereby students are being assessed for understanding and evidence of learning. Differentiation, scaffolding and student supports were also essential elements needed for students to achieve the learning objective of the lesson.    Ms. Martin understood that her lesson fell short from the planning stage through delivery, and that limited instruction on how to perform the desired tasks compromised student understanding. She explained that since they were Algebra II students, that they understood this Algebra I topic. My response to this was that the only thing you can assume in September is that they know nothing. If you assume nothing, review begins and moves forward at a pace dictated by the overall knowledge of the entire class.    We ended the conference with the expectation that Ms. Martin will work diligently on all aspects of the developmental lesson.

Ms. Hogue displayed a solid understanding of the Algebra II curriculum by including the Common Core Learning Standards in her lesson plan. Her plan also included details for guided and independent practice with ample teacher support.    The lesson objective stated that students would be able to identify and describe table patterns when solving algebraic problems. This objective represents important learning within the Algebra II curriculum.    Lesson activities consisted of students identifying patterns and predicting the next items/numbers in the pattern. Students also practiced identifying a pattern and created algebraic expressions to express the pattern. These activities represented a significant cognitive challenge to students. They will receive ample teacher support during this portion of the lesson.
column17: Ms. Hogue has built a positive rapport with her students very quickly. The culture for learning is positive whereby the students and teacher share a value for learning and working hard. Students exhibited enthusiasm and an excitement to participate.     Ms. Hogue is still in the process of establishing classroom routines and procedures. At the present time, her classroom management is partially effective in that some disruptions in learning occur due to impromptu, student-driven groupings.    As mentioned, Ms. Hogue’s students exhibit much enthusiasm while in her class. At times, their excitement leads to loud, off-task behaviors, as well as on-topic conversations between students. Since Ms. Hogue has not yet developed a hand system to volunteer to speak, students shout out their answers relentlessly, disrupting the lesson and limiting other students from participating. Ms. Hogue has a very calm demeanor. At times, she was able to redirect students with comments such as, “I thought we were working on problem 3b” and “I assigned student x to present.”
column21: Ms. Hogue utilized questions to drive directed practice, as well as clarify student misunderstandings. Her questions promoted thinking and, at times, led to class discussions. Most students participated in the discussions, however, a significant number of students did not participate.    All students were engaged in the lesson with varied degrees of involvement. Ms. Hogue did not make a dedicated effort to promote active involvement from all of her students. All students were on-task, and Ms. Hogue circulated the room to assist and assess students during independent practice. The pace of the lesson was appropriate, providing most students time to process and internalize the material.    As mentioned, Ms. Hogue incorporated questions to drive instruction. She assisted students during the independent practice sessions. When students were confused or off base, she remediated instruction directly with students. When Ms. Hogue noticed that numerous students exhibited issues, she would reteach certain elements for clarification to increase student understanding. The lesson did not include a final summary, nor a student reflection at the end.
column23: Ms. Hogue actively participated in the post observation conference. We discussed the classroom environment, and she was praised for the positive rapport that she has built with her students. A positive vibe exists in the class, and many students were extremely enthusiastic.    The lesson was rather lengthy and, in fact, this was the second day of a lesson that was planned for one day. Ms. Hogue and I discussed the need to generate and plan coherent lessons that include all the elements of a developmental lesson that last approximately 45 minutes. Lessons that continue into the next day, without offering a Do Now which revisits the lesson objective, tend to lack coherence and meaning. It is as if the lesson simply becomes a continuance of guided and independent practice sessions that lack continuity.    Ms. Hogue and I discussed areas for growth, including the development of classroom routines and procedures that add structure and maximize instructional time. In addition, we talked about the need to differentiate assigned work because of the varied ability levels in her class. Her high level students completed the independent work very quickly, while other students still required teacher assistance to complete their work. The down time for the higher level students resulted in off-task conversations and disruptions. We discussed the need to provide higher functioning students with supplementary work to challenge them and keep them engaged. This will afford Ms. Hogue much needed time to remediate and assist her academically challenged students.     Finally, we discussed the need for a final summary, which will allow students to reflect on the lesson and discern areas of understanding and misunderstanding. This will provide Ms. Hogue with a more accurate measure of student learning.     Ms. Hogue is a very calm, upbeat and caring individual. She is making a dedicated effort to improve her pedagogical skills and she truly appreciates suggestions and strategies that were offered.

column13: At this point in the semester, Davielle plays a supportive role in the 7th Grade Math class.  She follows lessons from a printed manual,  observes the cooperating teacher, and works with students independently or in small groups.  She has not written a lesson plan,  and I have promised to provide her with one aligned to the edTPA. Davielle has stated that she will begin teaching in front of the class next week.  So by the next time we visit, I should have more concrete comments about her lesson planning and delivery.
column17: Davielle approaches students with a soft spoken, friendly manner.  She loves her teaching position,  which is obvious by the way students react to her.  Davielle's cooperating teacher sets a good example of structure mixed with kindness.  Students are involved in different activities in order to vary the lesson and make it more effective.  The lesson I observed involved group work and review of problems in a 'seminar' format. Students were generally cooperative,  but it did take extra time to set up a discussion session.
column21: Since Davielle's supportive position involves her observing and working with small groups,  during this lesson there was not much evidence of questioning with students.  They were assigned to form a hypotheses and to work on their own, combining their findings during seminar.

column13: This lesson was part of a unit in which students were creating powerpoint presentations about some historical aspect of the Globe Theater.  Ms. Epstein had created a worksheet to guide them through the planning of the presentation.  She had been thoughtful in creating a task she felt was at students' skills levels and she was aware of each student's specific learning needs.  We discussed creating a project that would be higher interest and allow greater interaction with a text, as well as more opportunities for creative/critical thinking.
column17: There were no behavioral issues in the class, and Ms. Epstein shows clear love and respect and devotion to her students; her care for them was palpable.  The issues mentioned above in lesson and unit design contributed to lack of student engagement; we discussed how to not only meet students at their skills level but also to design high-interest units that would motivate them to reach higher on the taxonomy.  If students are able to take more ownership of the lesson, she will see a big increase in learning outcomes.
column21: See above for some notes on engagement as part of the classroom culture.  We discussed ways to assess how deeply students were thinking and how much farther they could go with that thinking.  Current use of assessment shows a basic understanding of how to gauge student mastery but this is an area in need of development alongside lesson/unit structuring.  She was teaching a mixed ESL and SPED class but with no SPED co-teacher who might have been able to help her with modifications and other ways to target SPED needs as opposed to language needs.
column23: Ms. Epstein is very enthusiastic about teaching and about her students.  She is eager to learn as well.  We discussed ways to listen more and speak less in her lesson; this will also benefit her in the reflection process.
